newsitem.title: UK: Booker makes agreed offer for Nurdin.
newsitem.headline: Booker makes agreed offer for Nurdin.

text.p: Food distribution company Booker Plc said it had made an agreed cash and shares offer for food wholesaler Nurdin & Peacock Plc, valuing Nurdin at around 264 million stg.
Under the offer, Nurdin shareholders will receive 14 new Booker shares and 154.53 stg in cash for every 100 Nurdin shares.
Based on a Booker share price of 360.5p per share, the offer values Nurdin shares at 205p.
Nurdin shares closed at 130.5p on Tuesday.
Booker said Nurdin shareholders may elect for a full cash alternative of 201p per share or to receive additional shares in place of all or part of the cash element.
Booker has received irrevocable undertakings to accept from shareholders representing some 28 pct of Nurdin shares.
These include charitable and other trusts asscociated with the Peacock family.
Booker said it expects to derive "clear and significant economic benefits" from the combination with Nurdin.
"The combined food wholesaling business will have major opportunities to improve its buying efficiency, reduce its costs and reduce its working capital," the companies said in a joint statement.
Booker said it expects annual cost savings of 10 million stg in the first full year and expects this to more than double over the following two years.
Booker said it will make a 52 million stg provision for one-off restructuring charges in 1996.
Nurdin chairman Richard Fulford said it had been clear for some time that the food wholesaling industry was in for a period of rationalisation in response to pressures from food retailing multiples.
